Posts.Title: Bra shopping!

Posts.Content: Hi Medusa, 3 weeks on from mastectomy and I am wearing a mix of bras, I bought some lovely mastectomy bras from Debenhams, all were £20 or under. My normal bras are not unsderwired, I got rid of those, but I find my softee travels, haha, which is why I went for the pocketed bras. My scar line is across of the centre of where my breast was, but because I had full node clearance I didn't want wires at present as it will just touch the top of the surgery site. Asda sell a range of mastectomy bras, which come in around the £10 mark, not sure if hey are in stores or online only. M & S also do bras, my local branch was online online only, and again they are very reasonably priced. I went to Debenhams as they had them in store and I wanted to come away feeling cheered up. Xx
Posts.Title: Prosthetic boobs :)

Posts.Content: Today I phoned my local Debenhams and spoke to one of the staff as to whether they had mastectomy bras or online only, they had them in store and some were in on sale she told me. I was so excited that my husband told me to switch the oven off, he was about to do some lunch, and we would go shopping straight away! Arriving in the lingerie dept, I asked where the mastectomy bras were, she asked me if I was the person who phoned earlier, to which I said yes. Well, what amazing service I received, first she looked through the sale rail for me, but nothing I my size, showed me all the different styles available, and then offered help should I have any problems putting my softee in the pockets. I wanted some matching briefs to go with one of the bras, which they didn't have, and whilst I was changing she sent my husband back to the changing room with an almost exact match. My husband was allowed to come in and see me once I had the bras on as I wanted his opinion on the fit. Amazing service and I love the very feminine and pretty bras. I have chosen moulded cups as I look even, I am on every happy bunny!

Posts.Content: I don't know about brave and an inspiration JJsailor, but your comment has made me smile. Posts.Title: Home- post mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Clump and Helen, things are still going well, I have very good arm movement, but do exercises every day. I do have a little bit of swelling under my arm and on the inside of my upper arm, keeping a close eye on it. The little shocks like to do their own thing, still odd and so far only had one that made me yelp! I have cut the meds down to half the amount, as I feel that level is right for me, plus I find they have made me constipated which I find more uncomfortable. I have had a few more tears, but that is fine, and I am ok with my body, I do have a knitted knocker which arrived this morning, it is so very comfortable and fits really well. I am truly grateful to the staff at the hospital, everyone of them was fantastic, and I think that helped with the all important start to my recovery. Clump, I wish you well for your surgery, everything will be fine, and you will be on the road to physical healing. Be gentle with yourself, and let others help, rest when you need to, try the exercises every day, and get well very soon, Pat xx
Posts.Title: Home- post mastectomy

Posts.Content: I had my mastectomy on Wednesday and came home today. I went down for surgery at 3pm and was back on the ward at 6.40pm, I was a bit sleepy in recovery! My surgery went well, and by 10am the next morning I was washed, dressed, and had done my makeup. I had looked at my wound site but obviously the dressing was in place, but I was not horrified by any means and can only say I felt a huge sense of relief that my breast had gone. I had one drain in place, my breast care nurse advised me to stay in two nights, as she felt it better to make sure the drain didn't collect more than 50ml, and to have it removed before I went home, and I was happy with that. The drain was removed today, it gushed a bit, and was probably placed about 4-5 inches under my arm. It wasn't painful coming out, just a slight stinging. Both nights in hospital I had an injection in my tummy, this is usual practice to prevent blood clots, and neither injection hurt. The pain killers I had in hospital and came home with are paracetamol and naproxen, an anti inflammatory. I am not in pain, I just feel a bit stiff. I tried on my bra about an hour ago with the help of my husband and placed the softie inside. Then the tears came, he was amazing and told me I looked fabulous, and without the bra I was just as gorgeous as ever! I must mention one all important thing, from the lady who came with the early morning tea to my surgeon, I was treated with great kindness, and professionalism. I do not have the words to express my gratitude to all those involved in my care.

Posts.Content: I had my MRI this week and went in feet first. I had my arms stretched out in front of me with some very comfortable pads placed under my arms to support them. The staff were really so caring, helping me off the scanner and covering me up before I was fully up on my knees to preserve my dignity. Although I was a bit apprehensive at first, they made me feel so well looked after, that everything was just fine.

Posts.Title: Bras after surgery

Posts.Content: Yesterday I went for a 2nd biopsy on a different area of my breast. I felt fine about the appt as I knew the drill. But since the appt I have confused and upset. Firstly the radiographer seemed to have no idea where she was to take the samples from, I pointed to the diagram on my notes where 'X' marked the spot and also the area of my breast where I knew the biopsy should be taken, but obviously not he exact spot! She huffed and puffed saying it was difficult. She then asked me why I was having the biopsy, so I told her because I had been diagnosed with breast cancer. She then asked my treatment plan, I told her that my first treatment was surgery, a mastectomy. To my amazement, she said very curtly, well why does your doctor want another biopsy if you are having a mastectomy, I was stunned, all I could say is because he does. She muttered some more and then said off the cuff, do you want a mastectomy. I could feel tears welling up as she carried on with biopsy saying it's not top of my wish list. When the procedure was over, she asked if I was having an MRI, which I am on Wednesday, good she said as that will confirm whether you have cancer in your right breast as well. I told her indications and test results regarding that breast showed no abnormalities, but that I was aware the MRI might show something up. I left feeling angry, firstly she didn't know where she was taking the samples from, obviously hadn't read my notes or would have known why I was there. Questioned my doctor's reasoning for the biopsy, which I know why, even though my response was lame as I had a brain freeze moment! Asked me if I wanted a mastectomy, now I am a bit confused, did she see something that made her think I don't need a mastectomy, , that's the thought whizzing through my head. Anyone else been in a similar situation?

You say you are on hormone meds, as I am, Each day I take one I think I am nearer to the end of my treatment, it helps me to try and remain positive. Posts.Title: Mastectomy, a week on

Posts.Content: A little over a week on from my mastectomy an axillary node clearance, and things are still good. Went to my GP this morning regarding swelling under arm and bingo wing! It has felt huge, and wondered what a normal amount of swelling was and when it tipped over to being a problem. Pleased to say it is normal, looked in the mirror which is better than my one at home and could see it actually isn't too much. He changed my dressing, and although the butterfly sticky things are in place, he announced with great joy it was one of the neatest surgical scars he had seen, hooray! No pain to the surgical site where my breast was and the chest area, and just for good measure I got the full once over of my remaining breast, great joy, haha. Underarm and bingo wing is the most sensitive and there have been a couple of occasions I have woken with a jolt and a yelp during the night, which has meant a very disturbed nights sleep. Other than that, all seems well and I have my follow up appt with my lovely surgeon on the 1st October. Hope everyone is having a good day, sending you all my very best wishes, Pat xx
